FTP - File Transfer Protocol.3: Authenticates with a username and password; Some systems use a generic/anonymous login
FTP - File Transfer Protocol.4: Full-featured functionality, such as list, add, delete, etc.

SSH - Secure Shell.3: Looks and acts the same as Telnet

Telnet.5: Not the best choice for production systems

SMTP - Simple Mail Transfer Protocol.1: Server to server email transfer - tcp/25
SMTP - Simple Mail Transfer Protocol.2: Also used to send mail from a device to a mail server
SMTP - Simple Mail Transfer Protocol.3: Commonly configured on mobile devices and email clients
SMTP - Simple Mail Transfer Protocol.4: Other protocols are used for clients to receive email (IMAP, POP3)

DNS - Domain Name System.1: Converts names to IP addresses - udp/53
DNS - Domain Name System.4: Usually multiple DNS servers are in production

HTTP and HTTPS.2: Communication in the browser and by no other applications
HTTP and HTTPS.3: In the clear or encrypted - HTTPS - tcp/443
HTTP and HTTPS.4: HTTPS is supported by nearly all web servers and clients

POP / IMAP.1: Receive emails from an email server; Authenticate and transfer
POP / IMAP.2: POP3 - Post Office Protocol version 3 - tcp/110
POP / IMAP.3: POP3 has basic mail transfer functionality
POP / IMAP.4: IMAP4 - Internet Message Access Protocol v4 - tcp/143
POP / IMAP.5: Includes management of email inbox from multiple clients

RDP - Remote Desktop Protocol.1: Share a desktop from a remote location over tcp/3389
RDP - Remote Desktop Protocol.3: Remote Desktop Services on many Windows versions
RDP - Remote Desktop Protocol.4: Can connect to an entire desktop or just an application
RDP - Remote Desktop Protocol.5: Clients for Windows, macOS, Linux, Unix, iPhone, Android, and others

SMB - Server Message Block.1: Protocol used by Microsoft Windows for file sharing, printer sharing; Also called CIFS (Common Internet File System)
SMB - Server Message Block.2: Direct over tcp/445 (NetBIOS-less); Direct SMB communication over TCP without the NetBIOS transport
SMB - Server Message Block.3: Using NetBIOS over TCP/IP with the following:
SMB - Server Message Block.4: • udp/137 - NetBIOS name services (nbname); Register, remove, and find Windows services by name
SMB - Server Message Block.5: • udp/138 - NetBIOS datagram service (nbdatagram); Windows connectionless data transfer
SMB - Server Message Block.6: • tcp/139 - NetBIOS session service (nbsession); Windows connection-oriented data transfer

AFP (Apple Filing Protocol).1: File transfer services in macOS - tcp/548
AFP (Apple Filing Protocol).2: File management - Copy, move, delete files
AFP (Apple Filing Protocol).3: Works with SLP (Service Location Protocol) - tcp/427 and udp/427 (Populates the list of available devices); Find Mac OS services by name

DHCP - Dynamic Host Configuration Protoc.1: Automated configuration of IP address, subnet mask and other options
DHCP - Dynamic Host Configuration Protoc.4: Server, appliance, integrated into a SOHO router, etc.
DHCP - Dynamic Host Configuration Protoc.5: Dynamic / pooled - IP addresses are assigned in real-time from a pool; Each system is given a lease and must renew at set intervals
DHCP - Dynamic Host Configuration Protoc.6: DHCP reservation - Addresses are assigned by MAC address in the DHCP server; Quickly manage addresses from one location

LDAP (Lightweight Directory Access Proto.2: Store and retrieve information in a network directory
LDAP (Lightweight Directory Access Proto.3: Commonly used in Microsoft Active Directory

SNMP - Simple Network Management Protoco.1: Gather statistics from network devices- Queries: udp/161, Traps: udp/162
SNMP - Simple Network Management Protoco.2: v1 – The original: Structured tables, in-the-clear
SNMP - Simple Network Management Protoco.3: v2 – A good step ahead: Data type enhancements; Bulk transfers, still in-the-clear
SNMP - Simple Network Management Protoco.4: v3 – A secure standard: Message integrity; Authentication, encryption
